content.description: Chimney climbing most of the way to a couple of face moves, with a couple of jams thrown in there as well.
content.protection: Standard trad rack. Bring one piece in the 3"-4" range for the top if you don't want to run it out. Shares anchors with Family Tradition.
content.location: Starts in the finger crack and chimney directly left of Family Tradition

climbs.name: Tong Shing
climbs.fa: Andy Pense, Sam Watson, J.J., Jared Hancock, 2005

content.description:
Crux near the 6th bolt.  Trust your body position and statically clip the 6th bolt.  Highly technical climb requiring forethought and deliberate maneuvers.

Enjoy the crimps and slopers.

Bring a Squib Clip for the first clip, or be sure to spot the climber until clipped.
content.protection: 6 Bolts, and 2 bolts for Anchors. Rap off to save integrity of the rope.
content.location: The next bolted line around the corner to the right of "Family Tradition."  Nearly to the corner.

content.description: Great beginning-leaders route.  Slightly vertical like most routes in the Red, but HUGE holds and ends before anyone should be getting any pump.  There in one hold in the wall that's kind of like a bumpy golf ball, but totally spherical; cool feature.
content.location: First route you encounter as you come up from the parking lot; starts just right of Helping Hand.  Belay is slightly steep, but firm soil; last time I was there, there was a belay station built up.

content.description: Short route with a bouldery start. Though the fingerlocks and reachy pockets provide a challenge.
content.protection: 6 bolts to first set of anchors
content.location: Right from Haas Memorial Route just before a cave

content.description: Clip two bolts than climb the lieback crack or use face holds. At the top, traverse left to finish at the anchor for Pinkies Extended.
Pull up pumpy but large plates to a ledge that you can get a no hands rest on before pulling the crux bulge. One more bolt takes you to the anchors.
content.location: On the far left end of Volunteer Wall. This is currently the 2nd route from the left.

content.description: A low crux and steep plates lead to a good rest before a cool boulder problem on pockets and big iron features.
content.location: Between Hurt and Same Way on the left side of Volunteer Wall, just left of the mixed corner with 2 bolts down low (Smell the Glove, 5.8)

content.description: Reach high for the start holds then surmount a roof to gain the slightly overhanging face.
content.location: 25 ft left of "First Time", just right of the cave.

content.description: Easy first clip followed by a tricky bulge and then rewarding slab climbing above.
content.location: Left of Helping Hands.

content.description: Similar in style to its left neighbor (Donor), though perhaps a touch easier. Candidate holds are less abundant than on Donor, however it ultimately feels somewhat less pumpy. The start (getting on the first ledge) is also significantly easier which may help with the pump. Maybe 10d is stiff, could be 11a.
content.location: A new route immediately to the right of Donor.

content.description: Tricky start from the roof followed by easier terrain on jogs and pockets.  Two large bulges that are hard to pull but big rests after.  The move to the anchors can also be pretty rough.
Starting off a boulder weave your way thru less featured rock to  a more featured section of wall above.
content.location: To the left of the main wall of Volunteer crag, about 50' right of Same Way.  Starts on top of a boulder, just left of either a water stain or a run-off water fall - depending on time of year.

content.description: Pull through a small overhang to crimps and slabby moves.
content.protection: 6 glue in bolts to bolted anchors
content.location: Right of Nice to Know You

climbs.name: The Haas Memorial Route
climbs.fa: Jason Haas, Sarah Maclean, Mark Johnson, 2005

content.description: Start at the back of the cave and follow the crack out. Once out of the cave, the crack becomes an offwidth dihedral to a ledge followed by a chimney.
content.location: Right of Stamp Meet and just right of Farley's Folley

content.description: bouldery start on some sandy rock, through a small roof to a huge stance. rest here then head up the overhanging wall with the moves getting less and less straightforward. fight the pump until you hit the final holds and clip the chains.
content.protection: bolts, stick clip the first one.
content.location: around the corner from "First Time" look for the line of bolts up the pocketed overhanging face.

content.description: This climb starts on top of a rock and immediately traverses right 10' or so to get to your first bolt.  Pretty straightforward climb, nothing too extreme (it is a 5.8 after all).  A great view above the trees awaits you at the top.
content.location: Take a right when the approach trail meets the crag - look for a boulder in a corner for the start.

climbs.name: Four Shower Tokens, a Guinness, and My Girl

content.description:
First, check for spiders. The sheer number of large spiders and webs make make this route unclimbable except for by the very brave.

From the back of the cave, climb up and right to gain access to a roof crack (#1s and #2s) followed by face climbing with jugs and ledges. Crux is pulling the roof at the start. Rappel from the anchors of Normalised Bramapithecus on the right.
content.location: Back of the cave to the right of Stephanie's Cabaret and Labor Day Weekend

content.description: Boulder moves on the start to gain the face. Head left and up on decent holds. Balance back right for the finish. In the early spring the starting holds can get iced over.
content.location: Left of a noticeable trad climbing area, left of Normalised Bramapithecus by about 75 feet.

content.description: Fun climb that starts in/near a large crack, sort of runs up the right side of 2 cool parallel curving cracks with a few tricky moves up high.  Unfortunately it gets a touch sandy near the top but still very much worth the effort.
content.location: Left side of Volunteer Wall, just left of an arete.  See photo.

content.description: Nice jugs and pinches to start.  Long upward throw to the top!
content.protection: Use a crash pad just in case.
content.location: Past the end of Volunteer Wall underneath the overhang.  Probably 10 feet along the bouldery area....

content.description:
This is a wall classic.  Smooth slightly overhanging and what looks like plated face.

A stick clip is advised due to the awkward and difficult start.  Make the weird moves to gain the face above the bulge.  Begin up the pocketed face with a difficult move.  Then continue to the many pockets to the occasional thin crimp.  Make a tough move through a few bulges to the easy finish under the capped roof.  This route probably stays dry in a light rain.
content.protection: 6 bolts to a two bolt anchor.
content.location: This route is on the wall just left of Wal-Martification of trad and Family Traditions and two routes to the right of Darwin Loves You.  A 60m will easily get you down.

content.description: Beging this fun route... Good holds followed by a great jug. Careful, don't pump out.
content.location: 100 feet right of the dihedral - right next to where the trail dips down.

content.description: Offwidth dihedral. Rappel from a tree at the top or walk off to the right.
content.location: Just right of Tong Shing

climbs.name: A Chip Off the Old Sturnum

content.description: Climb the right-facing dihedral to a ledge under a roof. Traverse under the roof to a crack that leads to the anchors. Check anchors for integrity before rappelling.
content.location: Around the corner to the right of Hurt
